Congratulations to our 5th grade students at Hilda Walker who organized and led a remarkable fundraiser for villages in South Sudan. After reading "A Long Walk to Water" by Linda Sue Park, Ms. Farrahi's and Mrs. Boudreau's students quickly wanted to find a way to help the cause of bringing fresh water to those in South Sudan. After months of fundraising and raising $2,300 from our community, a water well has been built in the Village of Panyuon in Aguok-North County, Gorgrial State. The village chief Majok Wol Majok sends his sincere gratitude to our students for making a difference in the life of all of his people. To see the village, you can use the GPS coordinates of 8.707364 and 28.363945.

Thank you to our community for participating in our fundraiser and for showing our students that Anything is Possible. It is the Walker Way!

Happy Pi Day!!!
March 14 (3/14)

Whenever students are asked what pi is, inevitably they reply "3.14". While this is the approximation of pi, few students can give its exact meaning or definition. Pi is actually the ratio of the circumference (distance around the circle) by the diameter (distance across the circle). Since all circles are proportionately the same exact shape, the value of pi will be exactly the same for every perfect circle. Our pi day activity gave students an opportunity to explore this idea. Students in Mrs. Nance's accelerated math class collaborated by measuring the circumferences and diameters of various circular objects and dividing them. While measurement is never exact, the values commuted representing pi should approximately average 3.14. Our computations actually averaged 3.2, which is pretty close. Through this activity students got hands on experience computing pi and gained an understanding of its true meaning.

First, students analyzed the literary techniques King used in his famous speech. The students learned about techniques such as allusion, extended metaphor, and anaphora (repetition). Then, the students emulated these techniques to write a speech about their own personal “dreams” for the world. Many of these students included research and statistics into their speeches, while also writing with the eloquent style of Dr. King.

post_text: Does matter such as air have mass? The students in Mrs. Hodys' science class settled a yes/no debate by completing a balloon lab. Students were given a balloon and recorded their observations before and after the balloon had air. Once the balloons had air, students needed to create a balance beam to make sure equal weight was present. Then students observed the result of air leaving one of the balloons. Surprise! Air weighs something, students realized quickly that as air left one balloon, it caused the balloon with air to fall to the floor. This proved that air has mass making the filled balloon heavier. Pictured are: Allison Reece, Gabriella Garcia, and Liberty Hunter.

post_text: The Escape Room concept is a fun way for students to work on various learning targets. Escape rooms are a team-based game where students crack codes, solve puzzles, and accomplished task in stations in order to accomplish a specific goal in a limited amount of time. Students in Mrs. Becker’s classroom did a culminating Escape room activity upon finish the novel Flush by Carl Hiassen. Having a shared environment in which players are working together on a game designed around specific learning outcomes sets the groundwork for active learning. Students certainly enjoy working in groups with friendly competition and having to use critical thinking skills to show understanding of the learning targets being practiced in class. Time constraints keep the students on task and working towards the goal of solving each puzzle. Students certainly accepted the challenges and work hard on trying to crack the codes. It is exciting to watch learning take place and sense of accomplishment the students would feel as they solved a puzzle correctly. Way to go Team Michigan ELA students!

post_text: Students at Hilda Walker School in ELA completed a project on indirect characterization traits. Indirect characterization is the process of describing a character through that character’s speech, thoughts, actions, and looks. An author will use this type of characterization to guide the reader in making their own conclusions about a character. Sixth grade uses the acronym STEAL to teach this concept. The students in Mrs. Becker’s class uses the novel Flush to demonstrate mastery of this learning target. Students selected a character from the novel, and then found evidence support a character trait demonstrating each part of STEAL. Indirect characterization strengthens writing by showing, not telling. This learning target helped the students draw their own conclusions as well as having to support their thinking with evidence. The students enjoyed working on this project in class.

District 161 administers 5Essentials Survey to improve school learning environment

Summit Hill School District 161 will join the Illinois State Board of Education in the seventh statewide survey of school climate and learning conditions. The survey provides a unique opportunity for our school community to have a voice in improving our schools.

The parent survey is now open. To access the survey, please use the link that was provided in an e-mail blast this morning.

From Dec. 10 through Feb. 14, Gr. 4-8 students and District teachers will be asked to take the survey to help identify strengths and weaknesses in their school’s learning environment.

The Illinois 5Essentials Survey provides a comprehensive picture of a school’s organizational culture in a school report measuring five “essentials” critical for school success:
 Effective Leaders
 Collaborative Teachers
 Involved Families
 Supportive Environment
 Ambitious Instruction

We encourage our parents, students, and teachers to participate to help improve our schools.
